text:
Raskolnikov stood in front of Sonia, feeling heavy with the weight of what was happening. 

“I’m late… It’s eleven, right?” he asked, still not looking at her. 

“Yeah,” Sonia mumbled, “oh yes, it is.” She spoke quickly, as if that would help her escape the moment. “My landlady’s clock just struck… I heard it myself.” 

“I’ve come to you for the last time,” Raskolnikov said darkly, even though this was actually their first meeting. “I might not see you again…” 

“Are you… going away?” 

“I don’t know… tomorrow…” 

“Then you’re not going to see Katerina Ivanovna tomorrow?” Sonia’s voice trembled. 

“I don’t know. I’ll figure it out by tomorrow morning… But that’s not why I’m here. I just wanted to say one thing…” 

He finally looked up at her and realized she was standing while he was sitting. 

“Why are you standing? Sit down,” he said, his tone shifting to something softer. 

She sat down, and he looked at her with a mix of kindness and pity. 

“You’re so thin! Your hand is like… a dead hand, almost transparent.” 

He took her hand gently. Sonia managed a faint smile. 

“I’ve always been like this,” she replied. 

“Even when you lived at home?” 

“Yeah.” 

“Of course you were,” he said abruptly, and the expression on his face changed.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov visits Sonia for what he believes may be the last time, expressing concern for her well-being while contemplating his uncertain future.
